facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 58 of 1959 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 7, 1958, of the Orissa High Court in Original Criminal Misc. Case No. 8 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 58 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 7, 1958, of the orissa High Court in Original Criminal Misc. Case No. 8 of 1958.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered on March 14, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR, J.-In this appeal by special leave, the appellant who has been found guilty of companytempt of companyrt by the High Court of Orissa is challenging his companyviction.

facts.text: The appellant was found guilty of contempt of court by the High Court of Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave, the appellant who has been found guilty of companytempt of companyrt by the High Court of Orissa is challenging his companyviction.

facts.text: The appellant was a Sub-Divisional Magistrate at Dhenkanal in the year 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Now we address ourselves to the merits of this case. The appellant was a Sub-Divisional Magistrate at Dhenkanal in the year 1957.

facts.text: A Magistrate III class, Dhenkanal passed an order under s. 522, Criminal Procedure Code putting the complainant, one Golam Mohammed in possession of some property.

anchor.surface_text: In a criminal matter  1  1936  A.C. 322. before him a Magistrate III class, Dhenkanal passed an order under s. 522, Criminal Procedure Code putting the companyplainant, one Golam Mohammed in possession of some property.

facts.text: The order was executed on October 14, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The order was actually executed Pion October 14, 1955. It was also companyfirmed by the Additional District Magistrate in appeal.

facts.text: The order was confirmed by the Additional District Magistrate in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: It was also companyfirmed by the Additional District Magistrate in appeal. It was, however, set aside by the High Court in revision on August 27, 1957.

facts.text: The order was set aside by the High Court in revision on August 27, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, set aside by the High Court in revision on August 27, 1957. The opposite party, one Sarif Beg, thereupon made an application on November 20,1957 before the appellant for redelivery of possession.

facts.text: Sarif Beg made an application on November 20, 1957 before the appellant for redelivery of possession.

anchor.surface_text: The opposite party, one Sarif Beg, thereupon made an application on November 20,1957 before the appellant for redelivery of possession. This application was opposed by Golam Mohammed.

facts.text: The application was heard by the appellant on November 21, 1957, and order was reserved till November 23, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: This application was opposed by Golam Mohammed. It was heard by the appellant on November 21, 1957, and order was reserved till November 23, 1957.

facts.text: The matter was adjourned to November 27, 1957, and the application was allowed with compliance directed by December 2, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Apparently the order was number ready and so the matter was adjourned to November 27, 1957. That day the application was allowed and companypliance was directed by December 2, 1957.

facts.text: An application was made by the complainant to the High Court for a review of its previous order.

anchor.surface_text: While these proceedings were going on, an application was made by the companyplainant to the High Court apparently for a review of its previous order.

facts.text: By order dated November 25, 1957, the review application was admitted by P. V. Balakrishna Rao who granted an interim stay of the proceedings before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Dhenkanal.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated November 25, 1957 this application was admitted by P. V. Balakrishna Rao He also granted an interim stay of the proceedings in the case before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Dhenkanal but did number direct that the said order should be companymunicated to the Sub-Divisional Magistrate by telegram.

facts.text: P. V. Balakrishna Rao did not direct that the order should be communicated to the Sub-Divisional Magistrate by telegram.

anchor.surface_text: P. V. Balakrishna Rao He also granted an interim stay of the proceedings in the case before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Dhenkanal but did number direct that the said order should be companymunicated to the Sub-Divisional Magistrate by telegram.

facts.text: On November 26, 1957, an application bearing an illegible signature was made to the Magistrate stating that further proceedings should be stayed.

anchor.surface_text: On November 26, 1957 an application bearing an illegible signature was made to the Magistrate in which, amongst other things, it was stated that the petition being number maintainable the opposite party has once more moved the Honble High Court in the matter and it has been ordered that further proceedings should be stayed until the disposal of the opposite partys revision.

facts.text: The application was accompanied by a telegram addressed to Mr. Neelakanth Misra, Pleader, Dhenkanal saying 'Golam Mohammads case further proceedings stayed, Ram.'

anchor.surface_text: Along with this application the companyplainant filed a telegram addressed to Mr. Neelakanth Misra, Pleader, Dhenkanal saying Golam Mohammads case further proceedings stayed, Ram.

facts.text: On November 25, 1957, the Sub-Divisional Magistrate was out of headquarters and the second officer directed that the application be placed before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate on his return.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear that on November 7 25, 1957 the Sub- Divisional Magistrate was out of,, headquarters and, therefore, the second officer directed that the application be placed before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate on his return.

facts.text: The Sub-Divisional Magistrate refused to act on the telegram and made the endorsement 'No action can be taken on telegram, File' on November 27, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Divisional Magistrate refused to act on this telegram but made the following endorsement on November 27, 1957 on what is said to be the companyplainants application No action can be taken on telegram, File.

facts.text: The Sub-Divisional Magistrate proceeded to deliver his order on the opposite party's application for restitution on November 27, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: He then proceeded to deliver his order on the opposite partys application for restitution. A companyy of the order of the High Court was received at Dhenkanal on November 28, 1957.

facts.text: A copy of the High Court order was received at Dhenkanal on November 28, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: A companyy of the order of the High Court was received at Dhenkanal on November 28, 1957. On that day the Sub-Divisional Magistrate was absent and the second officer made the following entry in the order sheet Seen.

facts.text: On November 28, 1957, the second officer noted the stay order, stayed further proceedings, and no writ for re-delivery was issued.

anchor.surface_text: Consequent oil this endorsement numberwrit for re-delivery of possesion was issued and thus the status quo was maintained. Upon perusal of the records on August 18, 1957 in companynection with the application for review made by the companyplainant the High Court ordered the issue of a numberice to the appellant on August 25, 1958 to show cause why he should number be companymitted for companytempt.

facts.text: The High Court issued notice to the appellant on August 25, 1958 to show cause why he should not be committed for contempt.

anchor.surface_text: Upon perusal of the records on August 18, 1957 in companynection with the application for review made by the companyplainant the High Court ordered the issue of a numberice to the appellant on August 25, 1958 to show cause why he should number be companymitted for companytempt.

facts.text: The appellant tendered an apology to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Finally he stated that if after companysidering his explanation the Court found him guilty of disobeying its order he expressed his regret and tendered his apology for what he had done.

facts.text: The High Court found the Sub-Divisional Magistrate guilty of contempt and sentenced him to pay a fine of Rs. 100.

anchor.surface_text: After an elaborate companysideration of the case law on the question of disobedience of orders by subordinate companyrts, the High Court found the Sub-bivisional Magistrate guilty of companytempt and sentenced him to pay a fine of Rs. 100.

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the review application by the complainant.

anchor.surface_text: By the same order the High Court dismissed the review application preferred before it by the companyplainant.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 7, 1958, of the orissa High Court in Original Criminal Misc. Case No. 8 of 1958. V. Viswanatha Sastri, H. B. Khanna and T. M. Sea, for the appellant. N. Sanual, Additional Solicitor-General of India, B. Patnaik, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji and Ramewar Nath, for respondent No. 1.
In this appeal by special leave, the appellant who has been found guilty of contempt of court by the High Court of Orissa is challenging his conviction.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the materials before us we are satisfied that the Sub-Divisional Magistrate was entitled to ignore the telegram as well as the application. We, therefore, hold that his refusal to act on the telegram did number amount to companytempt of companyrt.

holdings.text: there is no warrant for the practice which is in vogue in India today, and which has been in vogue for over a century, of, making the Chief Justice and Judges parties to an appeal against the decision of a High Court in a contempt matter. ... The present practice should, therefore, be discontinued and instead, as in England, the title of such proceedings should be in re the alleged contemnor

anchor.surface_text: Since this is the real position we think that there is no warrant for the practice which is in vogue in India today, and which has been in vogue for over a century, of, making the Chief Justice and Judges parties to an appeal against the decision of a High Court in a contempt matter. We may point out that it is neither necessary nor appropriate to make the Chief Justice and the Judges of a High Court parties to a legal proceeding unless some relief is claimed against them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judges decide matter without personal interest like litigants; no relief claimed against them; English practice uses 'in re'; no warrant despite past Indian/Privy Council practice

holdings.text: Before a subordinate court can be found guilty of disobeying the order of the superior court and thus to have committed contempt of court, it is necessary to show that the disobedience was intentional. There is no room for inferring an intention to disobey an order unless the person charged had knowledge of the order.

anchor.surface_text: Before a subordinate court can be found guilty of disobeying the order of the superior court and thus to have committed contempt of court, it is necessary to show that the disobedience was intentional. There is no room for inferring an intention to disobey an order unless the person charged had knowledge of the order. If what a subordinate court has done is in utter ignorance of an order of a superior court, it would clearly not amount to intentional disobedience of that court's order and would, therefore, not amount to a contempt of court at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mens rea required; ignorance or accidental/misconstruction not contempt; subordinate court must know and intentionally disobey

holdings.text: The knowledge must, however, be obtained from a source which is either authorised or otherwise authentic.

anchor.surface_text: The knowledge must, however, be obtained from a source which is either authorised or otherwise authentic. In the case before us it is not clear as to who the person who signed the application dated November 27, 1957 was because the signature is illegible. It was not countersigned by a pleader nor is there anything to show that it was presented in court by a pleader authorised to appear on behalf of the complainant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Knowledge insufficient without authorised/authentic source; mere information unreliable without verification

holdings.text: Upon the materials before us we are satisfied that the Sub-Divisional Magistrate was entitled to ignore the telegram as well as the application. We, therefore, hold that his refusal to act on the telegram did not amount to contempt of court.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the materials before us we are satisfied that the Sub-Divisional Magistrate was entitled to ignore the telegram as well as the application. We, therefore, hold that his refusal to act on the telegram did not amount to contempt of court. We may add that the fact that on receiving a copy of the High Court's order through the Additional District Magistrate not only were further proceedings stayed but a writ to redeliver possession was not permitted to issue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application had illegible signature, no affidavit, no pleader; telegram sender unknown/not from court/authorized advocate; stayed proceedings on official copy shows no intent

holdings.text: we do not want to lay it down here as law that every telegram purporting to be signed by an advocate or a pleader is per se guarantee of the truth of the facts stated therein and also of the fact that it was actually sent by the person whose name it bears. In order to assure the Court about these matters an affidavit from the party would be necessary.

anchor.surface_text: Of course, we do not want to lay it down here as law that every telegram purporting to be signed by an advocate or a pleader is per se guarantee of the truth of the facts stated therein and also of the fact that it was actually sent by the person whose name it bears. In order to assure the Court about these matters an affidavit from the party would be necessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Observation on telegrams requiring affidavit for authenticity; not laid down as law

precedents.citation: Ambard v. Attorney-General for Trinidad Tobago 1

anchor.surface_text: Ambard v. Attorney-General for Trinidad Tobago 1 we find that the Attorney General was made a party to the appeal. The question raised by the learned Additional Solicitor General is of some importance and we think it desirable to decide it. In every suit or appeal persons who claim relief or against whom relief has been given or persons who have or who claim the right to be heard must undoubtedly be made parties. That is because they have an interest in the decision or the result of that case. But where Judges of a High Court try a person for contempt and convict him they merely decide a matter and cannot be said to be interested in any way in the ultimate result in the sense in which a litigant is interested.

anchor.surface_text: The knowledge must, however, be obtained from a source which is either authorised or otherwise authentic. In the case before us it is not clear as to who the person who signed the application dated November 27, 1957 was because the signature is illegible. It was not countersigned by a pleader nor is there anything to show that it was presented in court by a pleader authorised to appear on behalf of the complainant.
We, therefore, hold that his refusal to act on the telegram did number amount to companytempt of companyrt.

Holding that Sub-Divisional Magistrate entitled to ignore telegram addresses issue by finding no contempt

anchor.surface_text: Upon the materials before us we are satisfied that the Sub-Divisional Magistrate was entitled to ignore the telegram as well as the application. We, therefore, hold that his refusal to act on the telegram did not amount to contempt of court. We may add that the fact that on receiving a copy of the High Court's order through the Additional District Magistrate not only were further proceedings stayed but a writ to redeliver possession was not permitted to issue.
We, therefore, hold that his refusal to act on the telegram did number amount to companytempt of companyrt.
